|Title=Know how to diagnose typical HUS
|Description=Know the signs of typical HUS, particularly in children (after bloody diarrhoea, fatigue, anaemia, etc.).
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Jean-Jacques Boffa
|Order=5}}

Combination of acute renal failure, haemolytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia following food contamination causing bloody diarrhoea. Diagnosis is confirmed by isolation of the STEC strain (shigatoxin-producing Escherichia coli) or PCR detection of shigatoxin-encoding genes in stools.

Atypical HUS occurs more frequently in adults, without diarrhoea, and is most often linked to an acquired or genetic abnormality of the complement pathway. It often recurs, particularly after renal transplantation, and has a more severe prognosis. Treatment is based on plasma exchange and/or complement inhibition.

properties.question: Which of the following is a key factor in diagnosing typical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) in children after bloody diarrhea?
properties.option_a: Isolation of a non-STEC strain of E. coli
properties.option_b: Presence of shigatoxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) or PCR detection of shigatoxin-encoding genes in stools
properties.option_c: Detection of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in blood samples
properties.option_d: Identification of a genetic mutation in the patient's DNA unrelated to the complement pathway
